name: Stoicism: Philosophy as a Way of Life
description: Control what you can, accept what you can't — the ancient philosophy that Silicon Valley rediscovered and that therapists have been using all along

name: Descartes and the Birth of Modern Philosophy
description: I think therefore I am — the radical doubter who split mind from body and gave philosophy its modern agenda

name: Kant and the Architecture of Reason
description: The man who never left Königsberg but mapped the limits of human knowledge — and grounded morality in reason alone

name: Hegel, Dialectics, and the March of History
description: Thesis, antithesis, synthesis — the philosopher who made history itself a philosophical argument and spawned both Marxism and existentialism

name: Nietzsche and the Crisis of Meaning
description: God is dead and we have killed him — the philosopher who diagnosed nihilism, demanded we create our own values, and went mad before the world understood him

name: Existentialism: Sartre, Beauvoir, and Camus
description: Condemned to be free — the philosophy that said existence has no meaning except what you create, and then argued about what that means

name: Phenomenology: Husserl, Heidegger, and the Study of Experience
description: Back to the things themselves — the method that studies consciousness from the inside, and the Nazi who made it famous

name: Feminist Philosophy: From Wollstonecraft to Butler
description: Reason has no sex — 230 years of philosophy asking who counts as human, who gets to know, and whether gender is something you are or something you do

name: Analytic Philosophy: Logic, Language, and the Limits of Knowledge
description: What can be said clearly — the tradition that replaced grand systems with logical precision, then discovered that precision has its own limits
